title: bad23
author: bad23
content: Being new to BTC I would like to know where the BTC are held that are for sale? I am learning as I can understand a complicated subject the deeper I dig into BTC. My stepson is a BTC bull, and he says I need to spend 1000 hours to understand BTC? Other than private wallets, is there a pool of BTC, and how many are there of the 21000000 total available? I am looking to buy more BTC ETF before I go deeper into buying the actual BTC wallet.

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: They ate still on the Blockchain Your private key gives you access to them. 1000 hours? Depends on what you plan on learning Basics wouldn't take up-to 5 hours not including practice. There are less than 118,000 Bitcoin remaining to be mined.Bitcoin ETF ain't actual Bitcoin but shares of the ETF issuer. You don't buy Bitcoin wallet They are used to keep and access your Bitcoin.

comments.author: DiMarxist
comments.body: Bitcoin are held or stored in wallets from the Blockchain. The ones you have are in your wallet and the other people also have theirs in their wallets and blockchain is where transactions are recorded. Decentralized wallets can be used to sell  bitcoin directly to one another without third party involvement and centralized exchanges are also to buy and sell bitcoin. Wallet is were bitcoin is stored. Though hardware wallet can be bought and not hot wallet.

find is a couple years ago your share broker/portfolio manager acted as sponsor to a ETF like blackrock whereby the sponsor bought bitcoin value. gave it to blockrock entrust, where blackrock put it into coinbase as custodian entrust. so that blackrock then can issue shares of a trust fund valued at the bitcoin valuation cap of that lump it has. to then allow the sponsor(your broker) to sell you ETF sharesthese shares are not ownership claims of bitcoin value(sats). they are just shares that represent a split up of a trustfunds valuation which pegs(follows) the bitcoin market price.. inshort comments.author: Zoomic
comments.body: The bitcoins are in the blockchain but everyone who own units of bitcoins store their bitcoins in wallets which they have control over. What gives them that control over the unit of bitcoin they own is their private keys, that is why everyone is advised to keep their private keys away from third parties to avoid unauthorised access. This is also why people are advised against storing their bitcoins in exchanges because there, you do not have total control over your asset.If you wish to own bitcoins, you can buy from exchanges or through P2P. Mind you, do not assume that Bitcoin ETF is same as bitcoin.  If you choose to buy Bitcoin ETFs, you still do not own bitcoins. Do not overstress yourself trying to learn about Bitcoin. Start with the basics and take things slowly. Bitcoin is very broad yea, but you don't learn everything in just a couple of days.

comments.author: Smartprofit
comments.body: Strictly speaking, bitcoins are not stored in the wallets of their owners. Bitcoins are stored in the blockchain. The famous science fiction writer Roger Zelazny believed that at a certain level of development, technology is already indistinguishable from magic. That is why I like to use magical associations when I talk about bitcoins. For example, you can imagine that bitcoins are gold coins that are stored in a parallel reality and never leave it. However, we, in our reality, have the ability to acquire ownership of them (that is, own them, dispose of them and use them). This is not a legal right of ownership, it is based on the internal rules of bitcoin itself (its algorithm, its program code). In order to acquire ownership of the first cryptocurrency, we need private keys (or seed - a sequence of several English words).  And in order to exercise our right to own, use and dispose of coins (or parts of them), we need the appropriate software, which is called bitcoin wallets.

comments.author: TheUltraElite
comments.body: Quote from: Zigabel on February 24, 2025, 03:58:40 PMTalking about where BTC are been held, it's mostly in wallets I mean people's wallets and sometimes that of institutions,  This is not completely correct. In simpler terms, Bitcoins are stored on the blockchain and the amounts owned by the private key is assigned in the public ledger. Your private key is what you need to access those coins from the public ledger. That is why you should never share your private key with anybody. Even if you wallet software is uninstalled, you never lose access to your coins, just install it in another device and plug in your key to regain the dashboard.Make this topics clear beforehand because you might get caught down the rabbit hole sometime in future.

Leaving your money in bank account can cause entire loss anytime, for example when bankrun happens, you can not do anything if you are not too early users who withdraw money and avoid death spiral of bankrun.
